item.title: Cyprus Adopts Bank Plan
item.description: Cypriot lawmakers adopted a plan that would close the island's second-biggest bank and see its big depositors lose more than a third of their savings.

item.title: Israeli Apology Resets Alliance With Turkey
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to Turkish Prime Minister Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship, a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries.

item.title: CIA Expands Role in Syria
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency is expanding its role in the campaign against the Syrian regime by feeding intelligence to select rebel fighters to use against government forces, current and former U.S. officials said.

item.title: Lebanese Leader Quits Amid Tensions
item.description: Lebanon's prime minister resigned, effectively dissolving the government and thrusting the country into political uncertainty at a time when the conflict in Syria is sparking sectarian tensions.

item.title: Russia, China Agree on Gas
item.description: After more than a decade of talks that were complicated by differences over price, Russia has agreed to supply China with natural gas, in a deal that could see China surpass Germany as the largest importer of Russian gas.

item.title: Italy Moves to Break Impasse
item.description: Pier Luigi Bersani, leader of Italy's Democratic Party, has been told by President Giorgio Napolitano to try to forge a government.

item.title: China Swoons Over New First Lady
item.description: Among Chinese much of the attention around President Xi Jinping's trip to Russia was on the new first lady, with many buzzing about Peng Liyuan marking a clear departure from her predecessors' low profile.

item.title: U.S. Confident of China on N. Korea
item.description: The U.S. is confident Chinese banks will fall into line with financial sanctions against North Korea, according to senior U.S. officials.

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Offices Targeted
item.description: Egyptian protesters ransacked three offices of the Muslim Brotherhood on Friday as anger over allegations of beatings and power-grabbing boiled over into the largest and most violent demonstrations yet on the doorstep of the powerful group.

item.title: France Drops 75% Tax on Rich
item.description: The French government threw in the towel Friday on plans to levy a 75% tax on the rich, and acknowledged it wasn't clear how it would hike taxes on the country's wealthiest citizens.

item.title: Myanmar Seeks to Contain Clashes
item.description: Myanmar declared a state of emergency in Meikhtila and four other towns around it, where sectarian violence between Buddhists and Muslims over recent days has left as many as 20 dead and at least 37 injured.

item.title: Italy Returns Marines to India
item.description: Bowing to pressure from New Delhi, Rome sent two Italian marines back to India to stand trial on murder charges, a move that eases—but doesn't end— a diplomatic impasse between the two countries.

item.title: Congo Rebel Leader in Hands of ICC
item.description: A rebel leader from the Democratic Republic of the Congo left Rwanda en route to the International Criminal Court in the Netherlands, becoming the first suspect to surrender to face charges of crimes against humanity.

item.title: Iceland Indicts 15 Over Crisis
item.description: Iceland's special prosecutor indicted two former chief executives and more than a dozen other ex-employees of banks that fell in the financial crisis that gripped the nation in 2008.

item.title: China Is Urged to Use Carbon Tax
item.description: China should enact a carbon tax and raise fuel and electricity prices if it hopes to tackle the pervasive pollution that is a byproduct of breakneck growth, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.

item.title: Rebels Approach Capital of Central African Republic
item.description: Rebels threatening to overthrow Central African Republic President François Bozizé advanced on the capital Bangui, after seizing control of the last bastions separating them from the city.

item.title: Chinese Tycoon Held in Connection With Brother's Arrest
item.description: Chinese mining tycoon Liu Han is being held on suspicion of harboring a family member who had been a fugitive from the law.

item.title: Mexico Telecom Reform Bill Advances
item.description: Mexico's lower house passed la bill that will make the biggest changes in decades in the country's telephone and television sectors, seeking to give the state enough power to guarantee competition and end monopolies.

item.title: Top Cleric Killed at Syrian Mosque
item.description: A top Sunni Muslim preacher and longtime supporter of President Assad was killed in a suicide bombing inside a mosque in Damascus, Syrian TV reported.

item.title: Militant Kurds in Truce With Turkey
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Kurds gathered to witness a call for peace, signaling the latest phase of a process seeking the end a three-decade conflict that has left 40,000 dead.

item.title: Hezbollah Plot Conviction Puts Pressure on EU
item.description: A Cypriot court convicted a 24-year-old member of Hezbollah on charges he plotted terror attacks against Jews last summer, a decision that could raise pressure on the EU to blacklist the Lebanon-based group.

item.title: Bangladesh Riots Threaten Its Boom
item.description: Troubles in Bangladesh are beginning to spoil its reputation among foreign companies, highlighting risks to investors looking for new manufacturing bases cheaper than China.

item.title: U.N. Elevates Probe of N. Korean Abuses
item.description: The U.N.'s Human Rights Council approved a framework to step up investigations into rights abuses in North Korea, providing more fuel to international efforts to pressure Pyongyang as it expands its weapons programs.

item.title: Science Fiction Comes Alive as Researchers Grow Organs
item.description: The science-fiction dream of building replacement parts for the human body has turned into a reality. In the quest to build a heart, researchers are tackling the most complex organ yet, and the payoff could be huge.

item.title: One Cheer for Corruption in India
item.description: For the indigent and unemployed, bribery is a way to share in resources long plundered by the better-off.

item.title: Achebe, Famed Nigerian Writer, Dies
item.description: Chinua Achebe, the Nigerian author credited with inventing African literature, has died. His best-known novel, "Things Fall Apart," sold more than 10 million copies in 50 languages.

item.title: Beijing's Spring Snowfall
item.description: Beijing residents woke up Wednesday, the first official day of spring in the Chinese traditional calendar, to a city blanketed in white after an overnight snow storm.

item.title: Diana's Million-Dollar Wardrobe
item.description: Kerry Taylor Auctions expects to raise more than £800,000 pounds ($1.2 million) with the sale of 10 dresses belonging to Britain's late Princess Diana, which are up for auction Tuesday.

item.title: Wu Led Village to Become China's Richest
item.description: Wu Renbao, who used "capitalism with Chinese characteristics" to turn a farm community into what is now known in China as the country's richest village, died of lung cancer.

item.title: The Brains of the Animal Kingdom
item.description: New research shows that we have grossly underestimated both the scope and the scale of animal intelligence. Primatologist Frans de Waal on memory-champ chimps, tool-using elephants and rats capable of empathy.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 22
item.description: In today's pictures, a boy carries a cross before the start of Holy Week in Spain, mourners pray in Bangladesh, police form a barrier in Bethlehem, and more.

item.title: Separatist Regions
item.description: One unexpected consequence of the euro-zone crisis has been the re-emergence of separatist movements around Europe. Jonathan House, Frances Robinson and Ainsley Thomson profile some of the regions across the Continent where the clamor for secession is reaching fever pitch.

item.title: Spring Is Here
item.description: Around the Northern Hemisphere, people are marking the end of winter with gatherings, rituals and celebrations.
